questions.statement: Youâ€™re looking for a new credit card and read something about interest.
questions.question: After comparing a few credit cards, you find out interest rates can be as high as 30%. Do you believe it?

questions.statement: Interest is the fee you pay to borrow money. This is also called APR.
questions.question: Credit card interest rates are determined by your credit, debt, payment history, and the economy.

answerChoices.answerText: All that is fine, but I can't control the economy.

questions.statement: Think of credit like trust. You gain trust, and therefore credit, when you can show you are reliable.
questions.question: The less debt you have and more you pay bills on time, the more someone will trust you with their money.

answerChoices.answerText: Got it! I still can't control the economy though.

questions.statement: And that's ok! If you have good credit and make your payments every month, you're on the right track.
questions.question: Just know the tougher these conditions are, the higher the interest if you don't pay it all off.

questions.statement: The Fair Credit Billing Act limits cardholder liabilities in the event of fraud. If charges are incurred after the card is reported stolen, the cardholder is not liable for ANY charges and $50 until the card is reported stolen.
questions.question: Your credit card has been stolen, and before you know it, the thief has charged $10,000. How much should you expect to have to pay?
In 2010, federal regulations changed, adding consumer protection that:

answerChoices.answerText: A. Prohibits card issuers from charging a penalty of more than $25 for a customer's first late payment.
Forbids 'any time, any reason' rate hikes.
Requires card issuers to ask customers whether they want to over-limit protection.

questions.question: A credit-card bill arrives on the 15th of the month; it's due on the 30th. When should you pay it to get the best results on your credit record?

answerChoices.answerText: The day it arrives in the mail.
Wait until a few days before it's due, then pay it.
You can wait until the 29th of the following month.
On time, but a few days before the credit card company sends payment data to the credit bureaus -- that way you'll show zero balance.
